SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: What do details in paragraphs 1 through 5 suggest about Amy and Todd?

A.Choice: Todd has different interests than Amy does.

B.Choice: Todd is more focused on school than Amy is.

C.Choice: Todd is more interested in watching TV than Amy is.

D.Choice: Todd has a different reaction to his mother's voice than Amy does.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: What does the word “straggled” in paragraph 5 suggest about Todd, Amy, and their father?

A.Choice: They are trying to keep the mother from seeing the kitchen.

B.Choice: They are determined to finish the work in the kitchen.

C.Choice: They want to keep close together in the kitchen.

D.Choice: They want to avoid going into the kitchen.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why does Todd and Amy's father refuse to look at the Sixty-Minute Gourmet cookbook?

A.Choice: He thinks that they do not have the skills to make the recipes.

B.Choice: He knows the family does not have the right ingredients.

C.Choice: He knows that the recipes will take too long to make.

D.Choice: He thinks that the mother will dislike the meal.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: The narrator's description of the conversation in paragraphs 1 through 13 shows that

A.Choice: the family has different ideas about a balanced diet

B.Choice: Amy knows which foods her mother likes best

C.Choice: Todd has experience with cooking

D.Choice: the father relies on his children's knowledge

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described.
Content: The illustration best supports the information provided in which paragraph?

A.Choice: paragraph 12

B.Choice: paragraph 13

C.Choice: paragraph 24

D.Choice: paragraph 27

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: How does paragraph 28 relate to paragraph 8?

A.Choice: Paragraph 28 provides further details about the problem.

B.Choice: Paragraph 28 shows the result of the mother's instructions.

C.Choice: Paragraph 28 presents a summary of the tasks that are introduced.

D.Choice: Paragraph 28 explains how the meal is unlike the mother's request.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which theme is supported by the events in the story?

A.Choice: Solving problems becomes easier with daily practice.

B.Choice: Challenges can give people opportunities for learning.

C.Choice: Doing work can help people forget their problems.

D.Choice: Feelings of guilt may go away over time.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: How do paragraphs 1 through 4 support a main idea of the article?

A.Choice: by describing how well Clara did at school

B.Choice: by showing how Clara's parents made decisions

C.Choice: by showing Clara's behavior around other people

D.Choice: by providing details about Clara's cousins

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why did Clara return from boarding school?

A.Choice: The people who cared for Clara were concerned about her health.

B.Choice: Clara was younger and smaller than most of the other students.

C.Choice: The teachers thought Clara could learn more at home.

D.Choice: Clara was unhappy because she missed her family.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 5.
:box:But it was a little late to rein Clara in now.
What does the phrase “to rein Clara in” suggest?

A.Choice: Clara was too old to play with her cousins.

B.Choice: Clara was often outside after dark.

C.Choice: Clara was determined to learn new things in the country.

D.Choice: Clara was unable to ride horses.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What do paragraphs 5 and 6 show about Clara?

A.Choice: Clara is active and adventurous.

B.Choice: Clara is obedient and intelligent.

C.Choice: Clara is quiet and cooperative.

D.Choice: Clara is creative and serious.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Why is paragraph 9 important for the article?

A.Choice: It explains why Clara was a good caretaker to her brother.

B.Choice: It shows a result of Clara's caretaking skills.

C.Choice: It suggests why Clara's great aunt inspired her.

D.Choice: It connects Clara and her desire to care for people to her great aunt.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: How did Clara's relationship with her brother David most affect her life?

A.Choice: By doing chores for David, Clara realized she enjoyed living at home.

B.Choice: By caring for David when he was injured, Clara developed a desire to help others.

C.Choice: By giving David his medicine, Clara learned about effective medical treatments.

D.Choice: By being home when David fell to the ground, Clara felt responsible for his injuries.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: Clara learned how to ride horses at a young age.

B.Choice: Clara had a great aunt who was a skilled midwife.

C.Choice: Clara was seriously hurt while ice skating with her cousins.

D.Choice: Clara remembered how good it felt to care for her brother.

SubTopics: Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.
Content: What does “take it up a notch” mean as it is used in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: to make more interesting

B.Choice: to become more forceful

C.Choice: to complete another level

D.Choice: to make another play

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 7.
:box:That candor might be hard for the members of the girls' basketball team at John Marshall Metropolitan High School to hear
What idea does this sentence help to support?

A.Choice: that Gaters can be considered impolite

B.Choice: that Gaters speaks very softly at times

C.Choice: that Gaters demands a lot from her players

D.Choice: that Gaters is impatient with her players

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 7.
:box:They know this is a woman who can take them places.
How does the author best support this point?

A.Choice: by explaining how Gaters helps many of her players attend college

B.Choice: by describing the long hours of practice Gaters makes her players perform

C.Choice: by providing examples of how Gaters helps players in need

D.Choice: by providing examples of the basketball tips Gaters teaches her players

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 21.
:box:But though Gaters is tough, it is a tough love, her former players say.
Which point in the article does this detail best support?

A.Choice: Gaters has a very strong desire to win so can get upset easily.

B.Choice: Gaters is unlikely to retire because she enjoys coaching.

C.Choice: Gaters cares about every aspect of her players' lives.

D.Choice: Gaters is nice only after practice or games are finished.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What does paragraph 26 suggest about Gaters?

A.Choice: Gaters is appreciated for her important contributions to girls basketball.

B.Choice: Gaters is considered the best high school basketball coach in the country.

C.Choice: Gaters has coached basketball almost as long as more famous coaches.

D.Choice: Gaters has been honored mainly for her work with students off the basketball court.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in two or more texts.
Content: How do paragraphs 27 through 29 contribute to the article?

A.Choice: by comparing Gaters's work ethic with Howard's

B.Choice: by showing an effect Gaters has had on Howard

C.Choice: by giving an example of Gaters's desire to win

D.Choice: by suggesting how Gaters feels about her job

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to the article, why do so many people respect Gaters?

A.Choice: Gaters teaches her players about more than just basketball.

B.Choice: Gaters encourages her players to play college basketball.

C.Choice: Gaters teaches her players about the importance of playing basketball.

D.Choice: Gaters wants her players to concentrate on improving their basketball skills.

SubTopics: Interpret figurative language, including similes and metaphors, in context.
Content: What does the simile “like an earthquake” in paragraph 5 help the reader understand?

A.Choice: that volume can strongly affect parts of the ear

B.Choice: that hair cells are easily damaged

C.Choice: how our body is unable to re-grow hair cells

D.Choice: how much damage the ear can take

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in two or more texts.
Content: How do paragraphs 4 and 5 connect to paragraph 6?

A.Choice: Paragraphs 4 and 5 explain how hearing loss can occur, and paragraph 6 explains how to prevent it.

B.Choice: Paragraphs 4 and 5 show what damage can occur, and paragraph 6 shows how it affects people.

C.Choice: Paragraphs 4 and 5 describe how the ear can be damaged, and paragraph 6 describes how people react to the damage.

D.Choice: Paragraphs 4 and 5 explain why ears get damaged, and paragraph 6 explains why protecting hearing is important.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which evidence best supports a claim made by the author in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: “If others can hear your music, the volume is too high.” (paragraph 6)

B.Choice: “Yahaira admits that sometimes after listening to loud music, her ears make a ringing sound.” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “So we need to protect that very special sense.” (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: “Music companies have been deliberately turning up the volume.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to paragraphs 9 through 12, how is the music business today different from the business in the 1980s or 1990s?

A.Choice: Today's music companies control the volume of music more than in the past.

B.Choice: Today's music companies compete against each other more than in the past.

C.Choice: Today's listeners of music like their music louder than they did in the past.

D.Choice: Today's sound engineers make music sound clearer than it did in the past.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which paragraph best explains how loud noises can damage our hearing?

A.Choice: paragraph 1

B.Choice: paragraph 5

C.Choice: paragraph 7

D.Choice: paragraph 13

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Draw on information from multiple print or digital sources, demonstrating the ability to locate an answer to a question quickly or to solve a problem efficiently.
Content: Which information explained in paragraph 13 does the drawing help the reader understand?

A.Choice: the shape of the parts of the ear

B.Choice: the position of the parts of the ear

C.Choice: the order in which sound waves strike the parts of the ear

D.Choice: the size of sound waves when moving through the parts of the ear

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which idea is most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: Music is not as powerful when played at quiet volumes.

B.Choice: Powerful instruments cause most hearing loss.

C.Choice: Choosing to play music quietly can protect hearing.

D.Choice: Music companies determine safe volume levels.

Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Content: In “[Excerpt from] Baby Mammoth Mummy: Frozen in Time!” and “[Excerpt from] Discovering the Inca Ice Maiden: My Adventures on Ampato,” what challenges did the discoverers face? How did these challenges affect their decisions about what to do with the mummies? Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• describe the challenges the discoverers faced
• explain how the challenges affected their decisions about what to do with the mummies
• use details from both articles to support your response
